field_edited_text.value:
14

SECTION D: CYLBURN PARK TO CITY LINE

29. Bird Refuge — Country Club Pond: With very little effort,
the area between the relocated Jones Falls and the original
stream bed can be made into a delightful pond and bird
refuge. The connection to Falls Road affords an access on the
east to pedestrian traffic.

30. Country Club Apartments: Over 40 acres of rolling, golf
course can be developed for residential use. Highrise towers
would meet many objectives made particularly logical by the
rapid transit and expressway. The hilltop at the northern end
of the site offers views and lookout development possibilities
that should not be lost to the public.

31. Parkway and Potential Development: Northern Parkway,
from Falls Road to Greenspring Avenue, should have parkway
treatment on both sides in order that it might serve as an
entry to the Valley. The slopes are steep on the north side
from Rogers Avenue to Greenspring Avenue, and the stream
in that area needs protection.

32. Private Recreation: The Valley floor reaches out to Falls
Road in this stretch. The area should be scheduled for ac-
quisition as the owners wish to sell. The future use might be
additional privately-operated recreational facilities similar to
those to the north.

33. Stream Conservation: The ravine and creek flowing into the
Valley proper from the west is again an integral part of the
Valley. The terrain is too rough for easy development and
much too beautiful not to be preserved.

34. Meadowbrook: The Mt. Washington Lacrosse Club and the
Meadowbrook swimming pool and skating rink are highly
desirable recreational uses; however, the City should work out
adequate means of assuring future land use control of this
part of the Valley. In the long run, similar recreational
facilities might be developed north of the Kelly Avenue via-
duct. The Mount Washington Methodist Church is of historic
and architectural interest and should be preserved.

35. Western Run Park: The junction of Western Run and Jones
Falls extends back along the Run to the Kelly and Sulgrave
Avenue intersection. This well-travelled intersection is an
important visual focal point for the Park. Retention of the
charming library building on Smith Avenue and the landscape
development of the remainder will make a meaningful junc-
ture of the Jones Falls Valley and Western Run. Along the
Run itself, the City should quickly acquire the remaining por-
tions indicated in Olmsted’s Plan.

36. Rapid Transit: The Northern Central Railway Line makes a
natural route for a rapid transit commuter line. This should
be studied at an early date by the newly instituted Metropoli-
tan Transit Authority. With rapid transit, the intensive
development along the Valley edges makes sense; and vice
versa.

37. Scenic Road: After underpassing the Kelly Avenue viaduct,
the Scenic Road will cling to the lower slopes below Mount
St. Agnes College out to the City Line. A few evergreens in
among the beautiful existing planting on this campus will put
the Road completely out of view from the College.

38. Lake Roland Connection: The stream valley, from the City
Line to Lake Roland, is relatively undeveloped, is almost en-
tirely in the flood plain, and is a vital link in the Valley Plan.
The 450-acre Robert E. Lee Park, known as Lake Roland,
is now owned by the City. It will become a natural destina-
tion for City hikers or riders making use of the Valley.

AREAS NORTH AND SOUTH OF DETAILED STUDY SECTIONS

39. County Extension: The Scenic Road should be extended into
the County, up the draw north of Mount St. Agnes, where the
size and beauty of the beech trees is breath-taking. The road
could have a connection with Smith Avenue. Winding on
through open country, it can join Old Pimlico Road where
that route will underpass the new expressway. Where Old
Pimlico meets Falls Road, a new access into Lake Roland
would be made, thus opening that rugged and beautiful park
to the public.

40. Scenic Road: From the new junction of Old Pimlico and
Falls Roads, the Scenic Road takes advantage of the existing
route of Falls Road, which needs only to have protection ex-
tended along its already beautiful borders. It will make a
magnificent scenic route all the way to Prettyboy Reservoir.
The County can realize this important regional facility with
the acquisition of scenic easements and development rights.

41. Inner Harbor: From Penn Station south to the Harbor are
chances for planting and enhancement of the expressway by
acquisition, by right-to-plant in railway areas, and by careful
control of future developments—both private and public—
adjacent to the expressway. The Harbor itself will eventually
be the dramatic and appropriate terminus for the Jones Falls
Valley. The potential of this area is unlimited. It must be
the subject of a study unto itself. As a natural resource of
historic and visual preeminence, the Inner Harbor is of great
importance to the City of Baltimore.
